content.rendered:
New for 2025: New entry for 2024

1971: The Bruce Springsteen Band is in residence at the Student Prince in Asbury Park.

1975: A scheduled show at the Rivoli Theatre in Indianapolis is cancelled.

1976: Bruce and the E Street Band continue their week of California shows with a stop at Santa Clara University.

1980: The original River Tour kicks off at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor, with “Born to Run” opening the show for the first time ever. Bruce is clearly a bit rusty, as he forgets the lyrics to his most well-known song. “Thunder Road” is played twice, the first time mid-set and the second as a final encore with Bob Seger.

1982: Bruce plays “Open All Night” for the very first time, not solo or with the E Street Band, but with Cats on a Smooth Surface at The Stone Pony.

1987: A couple of days ahead of the album it comes from, the first single from Tunnel of Love is released: “Brilliant Disguise.”

1988: Bruce plays his first and only show ever in Greece when the Human Rights Now! Tour stops at Athens’ Olympic Stadium.

1992: Bruce and his new touring band play their second of two World Tour 1992 nights at Phoenix’s America West Arena.

1996: Bruce plays a solo acoustic show at the Northrop Auditorium in Minneapolis.

2003: A stunning penultimate show for the Rising Tour at Shea Stadium from start to finish: Bruce opens with the tour premiere of “Roulette,” plays another double-header of tour premieres mid-set (“Rendezvous” and “Another Thin Line”), along with rare outings for “Janey, Don’t You Lose Heart” and “New York City Serenade” (another tour premiere). Willie Nile and Gary U.S. Bonds guest-star during the encores, and Al Franken makes a guest appearance during the main set.

2004: The Vote for Change Tour moves on to the next swing state–Michigan–with a show at Cobo Arena. “The Ties That Bind” and “Darkness on the Edge of Town” replace “The River” in the set, and “Travelin’ Band” makes its debut in the encores. The Dixie Chicks are in town for their VfC show, too, and they make it over to the Cobo in time to join Bruce and the assembled artists for the final encore. For more highlights from this show, see my Where the Band Was report.

2005: While driving his kids to school, Bruce notices on the radio that his favorite local public station is holding a membership drive. The station makes a plea for community support, so Bruce decides to provide it, stopping by the station with his guitar and spending over thirty minutes on-air talking with their music director and playing two songs.  One of them, “If I Should Fall Behind,” will be released on a promotional CD for pledging members.

2006: In an unusual move, Bruce re-releases We Shall Overcome: The Seeger Sessions in the same year as its original release, but this time as an American Land Edition, featuring five additional tracks and new videos.

2007: Live in Dublin (the video release, not the album) is certified gold by the Recording Industry Association of America.

2009: Night Three of five at Giants Stadium on the Working on a Dream Tour features the entire Born in the U.S.A. album along with the tour premiere of “Last to Die” and a by-request “Jersey Girl.” Jeremy Chatzky joins the band and Curt Ramm for “American Land,” and the set list continues to benefit from the presence of Curt and his trumpet.

2016: Bruce makes an appearance at Barnes & Noble at The Grove in Los Angeles to promote his new autobiography.

2017: Bruce makes his official Broadway debut when Springsteen on Broadway opens in its first public preview performance at the Walter Kerr Theater in New York City. Bruce dedicates this first show to Tom Petty, who passed away the day before. The show itself is an emotional tour through Bruce’s life and work, stunning those present with its power, poignancy, heart and humor–all of which will grow throughout its long run. I’m in the front row for this historic performance–read my account of the evening in my Where the Band Was report. Also in attendance tonight: Little Steven, Bruce’s mom, and Bruce’s sister Pam.

2018: Springsteen on Broadway celebrates the one-year anniversary of its theatrical run at the Walter Kerr Theater in New York City.

2022: Bruce films videos for “Nightshift” and “Turn Back the Hands of Time” at Samson Stages in Brooklyn.

2024: On social media, Bruce publishes his endorsement of Vice President Kamala Harris in the 2024 U.S. presidential election campaign. Although the endorsement itself was unsurprising, the passion and urgency of Bruce’s plea sustains for days through the news cycle.

excerpt.rendered: The original River Tour kicks off with a Bob Seger duet, Bruce releases an American Land Edition of his Seeger Sessions album, and Springsteen on Broadway makes its debut. Many, many more highlights inside.

jetpack-related-posts.title: Kingdom of Days: August 17
jetpack-related-posts.author: Ken
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: Bruce plays "I'm Goin' Down" for the first time, wraps up his legendary 1975 stand at the Bottom Line, and more. Plus: a half-hour of 1992 Detroit soundcheck and performance footage!

jetpack-related-posts.title: Kingdom of Days: December 11
jetpack-related-posts.author: Ken
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: Watch rare River Tour footage, a holiday performance with Conan O'Brien, an interview on Italian TV, and more.

jetpack-related-posts.title: Kingdom of Days: September 17
jetpack-related-posts.author: Ken
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: On this date: Born to Run hits #1, Bruce debuts his duet with Sting on "Every Breath You Take," and a tantalizing audio glimpse of a still-unreleased, never-performed original song.

jetpack-related-posts.title: Kingdom of Days: October 2
jetpack-related-posts.author: Ken
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: Are you loose? On this historic day: The infamous Bomb Scare Show, the kickoff of the Magic Tour, and the finale of the Born in the U.S.A. Tour--video and much more inside!

jetpack-related-posts.title: Kingdom of Days: December 3
jetpack-related-posts.author: Ken
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: Today in Springsteen history: Bruce releases two new videos, a star-studded holiday show in Asbury Park features the return of some notable set list prodigals, and an epic 20-minute "Kitty's Back." More highlights inside.

jetpack-related-posts.title: Kingdom of Days: November 21
jetpack-related-posts.author: Ken
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: On this date: Bruce releases his eleventh studio album, The Ghost of Tom Joad. Plus: the Seeger Sessions Tour wraps up, the return of forgotten classic "Song for Orphans," and Bruce plays his first ever show in Sweden. More highlights inside.
